title: Elementary Electronics
description: Introduces students to the behavior of the fundamental building blocks of modern electronic devices and the underlying scientific principles that make these devices work. Topics include analog and digital electronics, resistance, capacitance, diodes, signal filtering, feedback, operational amplifiers, Boolean logic, logic gates, and digital-to-analog conversion.

title: Special Topics
description: Covers specialized or emerging topics in computing technology and information systems. Content varies by semester and instructor.

title: Programming and Computation
description: Exploration of computer programming with emphasis on scientific, educational, and entertainment applications. Topics include programming fundamentals, user interaction, graphics, data processing, problem solving, artificial intelligence, object-oriented programming, and core principles of computer science.

title: Fundamentals of Cyber Security
description: Introduces students to the collection, preservation, and analysis of computer- and network-based evidence for corporate investigation and criminal law enforcement. Topics include cybercrime, network intrusions, footprinting, malware, financial crimes, and forensic tools.

title: Web Design and Development
description: Introduces students to designing and developing web pages using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Covers information architecture, responsive design, modern development tools, and usability principles. Students build a small dynamic website.

title: Management Information Systems
description: Introduction to the management of computing and information resources in organizations. Topics include hardware, software, telecommunications, database management, e-commerce, and business intelligence. Students use spreadsheet and database applications to solve business problems.

title: Digital Graphic Design
description: Introduction to graphic design principles, typography, color theory, and digital tools including Adobe Illustrator, Photoshop, and InDesign. Students create digital designs and participate in critiques.

title: Internship
description: Supervised practical experience in computing or information systems. Requires approximately 140 hours of fieldwork. Must be approved by the department, CAPE, and the student’s advisor. Counts toward internship requirements for CTIS and CNS.

title: Data Structures and Algorithms
description: Covers object-oriented design, inheritance, polymorphism, lists, queues, stacks, binary trees, recursion, searching, sorting, and algorithm analysis.

title: Seminar in Cyber Security and CTIS
description: Focuses on ethical and professional issues in computing and security, including privacy, intellectual property, reliability, liability, and current laws. Includes professionalism, internships, job searching, and resume building.

title: Operating Systems
description: Evaluation of operating systems and their organization. Topics include concurrency, synchronization, message passing, memory management, interrupts, and file systems.

title: Networking Computers
description: In-depth exposure to networking concepts, configurations, and protocols. Lab exercises include OS installation, network configuration, network design, and performance testing.

title: Information Design
description: Covers human-computer interaction, usability, information architecture, markup languages, and communication design.

title: Database Systems
description: Introduction to relational database theory and practice. Students learn ER modeling, normalization, SQL, triggers, stored procedures, and database application development.

title: Systems Analysis and Design
description: Covers techniques used in the analysis, design, and implementation of information systems. Includes user requirements, feasibility studies, project planning, and system life cycle phases.

title: Special Topics
description: Advanced or emerging topics in computing and information systems. Content varies by instructor and semester.

title: Independent Study
description: Individualized study under faculty supervision. Topic and scope determined by student and instructor.

title: Cyber and Network Security
description: Builds on fundamental cyber security concepts. Topics include risk assessment, IT security controls, auditing, compliance, cyber insurance, and emerging trends.

title: Digital Forensics
description: Introduces digital forensic investigation techniques and tools. Topics include registry analysis, file analysis, internet artifacts, volatile evidence, incident response, and metadata.

title: Internship
description: Supervised practical experience in computing or cyber security. Requires approximately 140 hours of fieldwork. Can satisfy internship requirements for CTIS and CNS simultaneously.

title: CTIS Capstone
description: Project-based capstone integrating skills from CTIS coursework. Students design, implement, and present a substantial computing project. Must be taken in the final or second-to-last semester.

title: Special Topics
description: Advanced or emerging topics in computing, cyber security, or information systems. Content varies by instructor and semester.

title: Independent Study
description: Individualized study under faculty supervision. Topic, scope, and deliverables determined by student and instructor.

title: Senior Thesis
description: Independent research project culminating in a written thesis and presentation. Designed for students pursuing advanced study or departmental honors.

title: Advanced Cyber and Network Security
description: Covers advanced cyber security operations, risk assessment, threat analysis, incident handling, business continuity, disaster recovery, security policy formulation, and legal/ethical issues.

title: Departmental Honors
description: Advanced honors research or project work under faculty supervision. Culminates in a formal presentation or defense.

title: Digital Darkroom
description: Explores digital photography and image editing using Adobe Photoshop.

title: Images of the Earth
description: Examines satellite imagery, remote sensing, and geospatial analysis.

title: Discrete Mathematics
description: Topics include logic, set theory, combinatorics, graph theory, and algorithms.

title: Ethics in a Digital World
description: Explores ethical issues in computing, privacy, AI, and digital surveillance.

title: Formal Logic
description: Covers propositional and predicate logic, proofs, and logical reasoning.

title: Experience Design
description: Introduces principles of UX, interaction design, and user research.

title: Business Ethics
description: Analyzes ethical dilemmas in business, corporate responsibility, and stakeholder theory.

title: Criminal Procedure
description: Covers legal processes, rights of the accused, and courtroom procedures.

title: Criminal Investigation
description: Explores investigative techniques, evidence collection, and case analysis.

title: Criminological Theory
description: Examines theories of crime causation and criminal behavior.
